import React from 'react'; import '../Duties.css'; import Navbar from './Navbar'; import Footer from './Footer'; export default function Duty5() { return ( <>

Fundamental Duty 5: Promote Harmony and Common Brotherhood

Article 51A(e) - Fostering unity in India's diversity

üß© Comprehensive Understanding

Article 51A(e) establishes a civic obligation to:

  • Actively foster social harmony across religious divides
  • Nurture fraternity among all linguistic communities
  • Bridge regional differences through mutual understanding
  • Counter caste-based discrimination and prejudices
  • Promote gender equality and inter-community marriages

This duty operationalizes the constitutional ideal of "fraternity" mentioned in the Preamble.

üìñ Detailed Explanation

The duty manifests through various constitutional and legal mechanisms:

  • Legal Framework:
    • Supports anti-discrimination laws (Articles 15-17)
    • Informs hate speech regulations (Section 153A IPC)
    • Guides communal violence prevention measures
  • Educational Initiatives:
    • National Foundation for Communal Harmony programs
    • School curriculum on composite culture
    • Ek Bharat Shreshtha Bharat scheme
  • Community Programs:
    • Interfaith dialogue platforms
    • Cultural exchange festivals
    • Neighborhood harmony committees

The duty balances individual rights with collective responsibility for social cohesion.

üìú Historical Context

This duty emerged from critical moments in India's journey:

  • Partition Trauma (1947):
    • Communal violence during independence
    • Mass migrations and refugee crises
  • Post-Independence Challenges:
    • Language riots (1960s)
    • Communal violence (1969 Gujarat, 1984 anti-Sikh riots)
  • Constitutional Response:
    • 42nd Amendment (1976) during Emergency
    • Swaran Singh Committee recommendations
    • Inspired by Gandhi's vision of communal harmony

üèõÔ∏è Judicial Interpretations

  • Indian Young Lawyers Association v. State of Kerala (2018) : Used this duty to uphold gender equality in religious practices (Sabarimala case). [2018 SCC OnLine SC 1690]
  • Mohd. Ahmed Khan v. Shah Bano Begum (1985) : Highlighted duty while addressing gender justice in personal laws. [AIR 1985 SC 945]
  • St. Stephen's College v. University of Delhi (1992) : Balanced minority rights with national integration concerns. [AIR 1992 SC 1630]

üîç Contemporary Relevance

  • Social media's role in spreading harmony/hate
  • Urbanization and mixed neighborhood challenges
  • Interfaith marriage debates and laws
  • Language policy and national integration
  • Role of cinema and arts in promoting brotherhood
); }
